interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information === Review Date: 2013/01/01 Average Rating: 4.9 Product Details: {'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Joe Wright'], 'Producers': ['Tim Bevan', 'Eric Fellner', 'Paul Webster'], 'Starring': ['Keira Knightley', 'Matthew Macfadyen', 'Brenda Blethyn']} Review Text: When version first came out, I watched it with great anticipation for liking it. I love Jane Austen, have a Jane Austen related web site, and I am pretty easy to please when it comes to Jane movies. But I really disliked it. This past week I thought I would give it another try, and watched it again. I still really really disliked it. I just think it was poorly portrayed. The Bennet family is made to look excessively poor, grimy and shabby, and not portrayed as the gentlemen's family that they were. Kitty and Lydia were just foolishly, cartoonishly ridiculous, to the point of absurdity. The ball scenes were frenetic and overly crowded, again to the point of absurdity. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth was not likable in any part of the movie - her portrayal was too modern. The entire pace of the movie was too fast - the dialogue was so fast to the point of not being able to understand it at times (and I am not old and I watch British period dramas frequently and so am used to the language). Mr. Bingley seemed a buffoon, which he is not. Mr. Darcy was just never appealing. Their eventually romance seemed implausible. The whole thing just seemed forced. Jane Austen's subtle humor was never fairly portrayed.

It seemed like they wanted give these characters a modern feel while keeping them in early 19th century setting, and it just didn't work. I'm all for modernizations and retelling of Pride and Prejudice, and am a HUGE fan of the Lizzie Bennet Diaries on YouTube.

Of course, by far the best Pride and Prejudice portrayal is the Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth 1995 BBC version. Well worth the $4.99 on Amazon Instant Video. [[ASIN:B0083IJWNC Episode 1]] Review Title: I guess I'm one of the few that really dislikes this version Rating: 1.0 --------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
I Love Lucy - The Complete Second Season [DVD] Lucille Ball (Actor), Desi Arnaz (Actor), Marc Daniels (Director), William Asher (Director) & 1 more Rated: Unrated Format: DVD Movies & TV, Paramount Home Entertainment, Comedy ['Product Description', 'From its 1951 premiere to the present day,', 'I Love Lucy', 'has never been off the air! You’ll see why in this hilarious five-disc DVD collection, containing the show’s entire second season. Laugh out loud at such gems as “Job Switching”—in which Lucy and Ethel do unforgettable battle with a chocolate factory conveyor belt; “ The Handcuffs”—in which Lucy cuffs herself to Ricky and then loses the key; and “The Operetta”—in which Lucy’s money problems bring down the curtain on her role as “Queen of the Gypsies.” This collection also includes the groundbreaking “pregnancy shows,” including the touching moment at the Tropicana when Lucy breaks the news to Ricky that they are going to have a baby; and “Lucy Goes to the Hospital”—the record-setting episode that garnered the highest rating in the history of television!', 'Amazon.com', 'Season 2 of', 'I Love Lucy', 'includes two of the most famous half-hours in television history. "Job Switching," originally broadcast mid-September of 1952, is the crazy, battle-of-the-sexes episode in which husbands Ricky Ricardo (Desi Arnaz) and Fred Mertz (William Frawley) trade roles with wives Lucy (Lucille Ball) and Ethel (Vivian Vance), culminating in the men making a shambles of domestic chores while Lucy and Ethel take disastrous work at a chocolate factory. That\'s right: This is the show where the ladies have a Chaplinesque experience with a too-fast factory conveyor belt, forcing them to hide candies in their mouths, in their hats, and down their blouses lest a tough forewoman fire them for incompetence. A half-century later, the scene is still so fresh and funny it would grace any current sitcom. "Lucy Goes to the Hospital," which received an amazing 71.7 rating on January 19, 1953, is the historic episode featuring the birth of Little Ricky and a load of wonderful slapstick. Other television series (', 'The Dick Van Dyke Show', ') and movies (', 'Nine Months', ') have tried to top', 'Lucy', "'s time-to-go-to-the-hospital shenanigans, but there's nothing like the sight of Ricky and Fred falling all over themselves or Ricky showing up at the maternity ward (direct from a voodoo-themed show at the Tropicana) in witch doctor makeup.", 'The other 31 episodes included in', 'I Love Lucy: The Compete Second Season', 'have choice moments, too. "Lucy Becomes a Sculptress" finds the ever-ambitious redhead falling for empty flattery at an art-supply store and commencing an ill-advised career working in clay. Ricky agrees to bless this new endeavor if an art critic says she has talent, but Lucy tries to increase her chances by posing as a bust of herself--resulting in mayhem, of course. The usual running themes in', 'I Love Lucy', "--Lucy's misguided desire to be a part of Ricky's musical career, and her penchant for disguising herself to investigate something--are all over", 'The Complete Second Season', '. "Ricky Loses His Voice" is a delightful piece in which Ricky\'s laryngitis inspires Lucy, the Mertzes, and an aging chorus line to put on a Tropicana spectacle, and "Ricky Has Labor Pains" finds Lucy and Ethel going undercover as male reporters to find out what happens at a stag party. Lots to enjoy here, and the special features include bloopers, information about the guest cast, and snippets from Ball\'s radio show.', '--Tom Keogh'] {'Genre': 'Romance, Comedy', 'Format': 'Box set, Black & White, Dolby, DVD, Full Screen, NTSC, Subtitled', 'Contributor': 'Richard Reeves, Veola Vonn, Madelyn Davis, Bob Carroll Jr., William Asher, Marc Daniels, Carol Richards, Richard Lee Simmons, Jess Oppenheimer, Jerry Hausner, Vivian Vance, Desi Arnaz, Frank Gerstle, William Frawley, Will Wright, Paul Dubov, Lucille BallRichard Reeves, Veola Vonn, Madelyn Davis, Bob Carroll Jr., William Asher, Marc Daniels, Carol Richards, Richard Lee Simmons, Jess Oppenheimer, Jerry Hausner, Vivian Vance, Desi Arnaz, Frank Gerstle, William Frawley, Will Wright, Paul Dubov, Lucille Ball See more', 'Language': 'Unqualified, English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Mono), Spanish (Dolby Digital 2.0 Mono)', 'Number Of Discs': '5', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.33:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'Unrated (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '7.75 x 5.5 x 1.75 inches; 15.2 Ounces', 'Item model number': '2238096', 'Director': 'Marc Daniels, William Asher', 'Media Format': 'Box set, Black & White, Dolby, DVD, Full Screen, NTSC, Subtitled', 'Run time': '13 hours and 19 minutes', 'Release date': 'August 31, 2004', 'Actors': 'Lucille Ball, Desi Arnaz, Vivian Vance, William Frawley, Paul Dubov', 'Dubbed': 'English', 'Subtitles': 'Spanish', 'Studio': 'Paramount', 'Writers': 'Bob Carroll Jr., Jess Oppenheimer, Madelyn Davis', 'Number of discs': '5'} I'm an old fuddy-duddy! I don't want my kids (ages 8 and almost 6) watching 99% of the garbage that is on TV outside of PBS. But they are getting too old for Sesame Street. So where to turn? I've found help in my old friend Lucy. We have bought Season One of I Love Lucy on DVD, and the kids think it is the funniest thing ever. I enjoy watching it with them, and I laugh all over again. Season one has Vitmeatavegemin, and the kids laugh hysterically on the ground everytime they watch it. I can't wait to show them the Chocolate factory. The only caveat we need to do is explain about the cigarette smoking that goes on on the show. We just explain that "back then" no one knew how bad smoking was for your health, and they are fine with that. It's a great alternative to SpongeBob, I can tell you that! I Love Lucy - a great alternative to the current junk on TV {'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]', 'Español', 'Português'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]', 'Español', 'Português'], 'Directors': ['Mark Cendrowski', 'Anthony Rich', 'Peter Chakos', 'Nikki Lorre', 'James Burrows', 'Howard Murray', 'Gay Linvill', 'Kristy Cecil', 'Ted Wass', 'Andrew D. Weyman'], 'Producers': ['Not Specified'], 'Starring': ['Johnny Galecki', 'Jim Parsons', 'Kaley Cuoco'], 'Studio': ['Discovery Global']} I don't watch much TV, but I love The Big Bang Theory. It's funny in a nerdy way. The characters are so well played, there are times I forget Sheldon Cooper is not a real person! The writing in this show is amazing - I am constantly wondering "how do they come up with this stuff" as I'm laughing hysterically. I hate broadcast TV in general but I love The Big Bang Theory {'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Joe Wright'], 'Producers': ['Tim Bevan', 'Eric Fellner', 'Paul Webster'], 'Starring': ['Keira Knightley', 'Matthew Macfadyen', 'Brenda Blethyn']} When version first came out, I watched it with great anticipation for liking it. I love Jane Austen, have a Jane Austen related web site, and I am pretty easy to please when it comes to Jane movies. But I really disliked it. This past week I thought I would give it another try, and watched it again. I still really really disliked it. I just think it was poorly portrayed. The Bennet family is made to look excessively poor, grimy and shabby, and not portrayed as the gentlemen's family that they were. Kitty and Lydia were just foolishly, cartoonishly ridiculous, to the point of absurdity. The ball scenes were frenetic and overly crowded, again to the point of absurdity. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth was not likable in any part of the movie - her portrayal was too modern. The entire pace of the movie was too fast - the dialogue was so fast to the point of not being able to understand it at times (and I am not old and I watch British period dramas frequently and so am used to the language). Mr. Bingley seemed a buffoon, which he is not. Mr. Darcy was just never appealing. Their eventually romance seemed implausible. The whole thing just seemed forced. Jane Austen's subtle humor was never fairly portrayed.

It seemed like they wanted give these characters a modern feel while keeping them in early 19th century setting, and it just didn't work. I'm all for modernizations and retelling of Pride and Prejudice, and am a HUGE fan of the Lizzie Bennet Diaries on YouTube.

Of course, by far the best Pride and Prejudice portrayal is the Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth 1995 BBC version. Well worth the $4.99 on Amazon Instant Video. [[ASIN:B0083IJWNC Episode 1]] I guess I'm one of the few that really dislikes this version
profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

- **Content Preference:** The user prefers classic family-friendly humor and vintage television shows, like *I Love Lucy*, while seeking quality entertainment that promotes wholesome family viewing.

- **Family Viewing:** They prioritize media suitable for children, actively searching for alternatives to mainstream shows they deem unsuitable for family watching.

- **Nostalgia:** A strong fondness for nostalgic content motivates them to relive childhood favorites and introduce similar experiences to their children.

- **Parental Guidance:** They are mindful of children’s content, providing context for outdated elements in older shows, such as discussing smoking.

- **High Rating Expectation:** The user typically rates media very highly (often 5.0) and favors well-received entertainment, showcasing a preference for quality in viewing choices.

- **Sense of Humor:** They enjoy humor that elicits genuine laughter, particularly clever writing and relatable characters that enhance family viewing experiences.

- **Broader Comedy Appreciation:** Recently, the user has appreciated contemporary comedies with a nerdy sense of humor, indicating a broadened taste while still valuing family-friendly content.

- **Critical Viewing of Adaptations:** The user expresses strong opinions on adaptations, indicating a discerning taste. They showed disappointment in a recent film adaptation, favoring faithful representations of classic literature and characters while appreciating modern takes that respect original storylines. They highlight a preference for adaptations that capture subtle humor and character depth rather than forceful portrayals.
